awd_titl_txt: Multiphase Chemistry of Reactive Oxygen Species and Free Radicals in Secondary Organic Aerosols
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is funded by the Environmental Chemical Sciences Program in the Chemistry Division at the National Science Foundation. Professor Shiraiwa, his graduate student and postdoctoral fellow investigate atmospheric fine particulate matter, or aerosols. Organic particles are a major component of these aerosols. These particles influence climate, air quality and public health. Reactive oxygen species (ROS) including hydroxyl (OH) and organic radicals play a central role in the chemical changes that take place in organic compounds in the atmosphere. ROS are poorly quantified in cloud droplets and their role in aqueous chemistry is poorly characterized. This causes major uncertainties in evaluating aerosol effects on air quality.  Professor Shiraiwa organizes an annual educational seminar for local high school teachers. This educational seminar consists of three major activities: seminar, AirUCI lab tour, and hands-on experiments. With help from his research group, high school teachers operate instrumentation to measure free radicals contained in a variety of samples such as atmospheric particles, diesel exhaust particles, and tobacco ash. This research project advances the national health and prosperity by developing a better understanding of our environment and how it can influence human health. 

The project studies the chemical mechanism of ROS formation from atmospheric organic compounds. Organic particles are generated in a reaction chamber. Ambient particles are also collected using a particle impactor. ROS in organic particles are quantified mainly using electron paramagnetic resonance spectroscopy with a spin trapping technique. A chemical kinetic model is developed and applied for data analysis and interpretation. The project goal is to advance the fundamental understanding of multiphase chemistry of ROS in atmospheric water. The project involves mentoring of undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral students. An annual educational seminar on environmental radical chemistry is organized for local high school teachers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Organic particles account for a major fraction of atmospheric fine particulate matter (PM), influencing climate, air quality and public health. Reactive oxygen species (ROS) including hydroxyl radical, superoxide, hydrogen peroxide and organic radicals play a central role in chemical evolution of organic compounds in the atmosphere. ROS are so far poorly quantified in aerosol particles and their role in aqueous chemistry is poorly characterized, causing a major uncertainty in evaluating aerosol effects on air quality. The project aimed at elucidating the chemical mechanism of ROS formation induced by chemical reactions of atmospheric secondary organic aerosols (SOA). SOA particles were generated in a reaction chamber and ambient particles were also collected using an impactor. ROS associated with SOA particles were quantified mainly using electron paramagnetic resonance spectroscopy with a spin trapping technique. A chemical kinetic model was developed and applied for data analysis and interpretation. Through these research activities, we found dominant formation of superoxide from aqueous reactions of biogenic SOA. Organic hydroperoxides were found to undergo aqueous-phase decomposition upon interaction with iron ions to form hydroxyl and organic radicals. We identified iron redox cycling enhances organic radical formation from decomposition of organic peroxides in SOA. In addition, we collected atmospheric particulate matter next to highways to quantify environmentally persistent free radicals (EPFRs) contained in PM2.5 and the generation of ROS in water. The formed ROS are correlated with PM mass concentrations and OH radicals show a good correlation with EPFRs. ROS is also formed by various PM redox-active chemical components and we observed a complex relationship between ROS formation and PM oxidative potential. We advanced the fundamental understanding of multiphase chemistry of ROS in atmospheric water for better assessment of aerosol effects on air quality. Seven manuscripts were published in high quality peer-reviewed journals. For outreach activity, an educational seminar on environmental radical chemistry was organized for local junior high school students.

 


Last Modified: 10/13/2021
Modified by: Manabu Shiraiwa
